required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy Study Regarding the Beneficial Effects of Omega-3 Fatty Acids on Cardiometabolic Health
clinical_study.official_title: Omega-3 Fatty Acids and Genes Interact to Influence Cardiometabolic Health.

brief_summary.textblock: Fish oil supplements (which are rich in omega-3 fatty acids) have been shown to provide cardiometabolic benefits to individuals of all ages. Specifically, the daily consumption of fish oil supplements has been reported to reduce blood triglyceride levels, and influence glucose homeostasis and whole-body inflammation. However, recent evidence highlights important gaps in our understanding with respect to the impact of fish oil supplements on health; specifically, not everyone responds to these supplements in the same manner. The goal of this research is to explore how an individual's genetic make-up may modify their response to fish oil supplements.

detailed_description.textblock:
The typical Western diet is now recognized to have insufficient amounts of omega-3 fatty acids (in particular EPA and DHA). These fatty acids have several known health benefits, including improvements in heart health, metabolic syndrome, and inflammation. These benefits occur because omega-3 fatty acids can regulate a myriad of cellular functions. In order to increase the levels of these omega-3 fatty acids in the body, individuals must either consume more marine products or take an omega-3 rich dietary supplement, such as fish oil. While fish oil supplements are commonly consumed by people, it is now recognized that not everyone responds to these supplements in the same manner. Therefore this study aims to improve our understanding of why people respond differently to the same dietary supplement. The goals of this research will be accomplished using a number of approaches:
1. The investigators will examine how fish oil supplementation leads to an enrichment of EPA and DHA in various cells throughout the body (erythrocytes, adipose tissue, etc).
2. The investigators will determine the dynamic changes in EPA and DHA incorporation into different cell-types during distinct phases of our dietary intervention study (e.g. during supplementation and subsequent wash out periods).
3. The investigators will study how fish oil supplements influence various blood markers of cardiometabolic health (e.g. triglycerides, cholesterol, glucose, C-reactive protein, etc) and whether this is modulated by an individual's genotype.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Pharmacokinetics/Dynamics Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: Blood lipids (e.g. triglycerides and cholesterol) and fatty acids measured at distinct time points: baseline, after 3 months supplementation, and after a 2 month wash out period.

secondary_outcome.description: Blood glucose and insulin levels measured at distinct time points: baseline, after 3 months supplementation, and after a 2 month wash out period.

other_outcome.description: A blood sample collected at the beginning of the study will be used to collect DNA in order to examine an individual's genotype.
RNA will be isolated from peripheral blood mononuclear cells collected from a blood sample taken at baseline, after 3 months supplementation, and after a 2 month washout period.

arm_group.description: Fish oil supplements providing up to 3g per day of EPA and DHA
Placebo group will consume an equivalent number of olive oil capsules (relative to fish oil capsules) per day.

intervention.description: Participants are instructed to consume fish oil supplements on a daily basis for a 3-month period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- between 18-25 years old
- male
- good general health
Exclusion Criteria:
- currently taking a fish oil supplement
- currently taking an omega-3 supplement
- currently consuming a diet high in omega-3 (high in ALA, EPA, or DHA)
- not able to maintain a consistent lifestyle routine throughout the study duration
- have an allergy which would prevent them from taking a fish oil pill
- schedule conflict with study visits
- overweight or obese

facility.name: University of Guelph - Human Nutraceutical Research Unit

results_reference.citation: Zulyniak MA, Perreault M, Gerling C, Spriet LL, Mutch DM. Fish oil supplementation alters circulating eicosanoid concentrations in young healthy men. Metabolism. 2013 Aug;62(8):1107-13. doi: 10.1016/j.metabol.2013.02.004. Epub 2013 Mar 21.
